dublin_core.dcvalue: Although telemedicine may help overcome geographic access barriers it is unknown whether rural patients receive greater benefits In a secondary analysis of 503 veterans participating in a hypertension telemedicine study the authors hypothesized that patients with greater travel distances would have greater improvements in 18 month systolic blood pressure SBP Patients were categorized by telemedicine exposure and travel distance to primary care derived from zip codes Comparisons were 1 usual care UC distance Under30 miles reference 2 UC distance 30 miles 3 telemedicine distance Under30 miles 4 telemedicine distance 30 miles Compared with patients receiving UC distance Under30 miles intercept 127 7 no difference in 18 month SBP was observed in patients receiving UC distance 30 miles 0 13 mm Hg 95 confidence interval 6 6 to 6 8 telemedicine distance Under30 miles 1 1 mm Hg 7 3 to 5 2 telemedicine distance 30 miles 0 80 mm Hg 6 6 to 5 1 Although telemedicine may help overcome geographic access barriers additional studies are needed to identify patients most likely to benefit
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-07T13:44:40Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2013-10-03
Blood pressure control in a hypertension telemedicine intervention: does distance to primary care matter?
